documents.title: Docker Basics: Containerization for Beginners
documents.content: Docker Basics Containerization for Beginners What is Docker Docker is a containerization platform that packages your application and all its dependencies into a single unit called a container Virtual Machines vs Containers VMs simulate entire operating systems with massive overhead Containers share the host OS kernel much lighter and faster Key Concepts Images Docker image is a template or blueprint Containers A container is a running instance of a Docker image Registry Docker Hub is the official Docker registry Getting Started Installing Docker Verifying installation Your First Container Running a simple container Conclusion Docker fundamentally changed how we think about deployment

documents.title: Understanding Linux File Permissions
documents.content: Understanding Linux File Permissions File permissions determine who can read write or execute a file There are three categories of users Owner User The person who created the file Group A set of users with shared permissions Others Everyone else on the system Reading Permission Notation ls -l shows rw-r--r-- Breaking down permissions Owner permissions read write no execute Group permissions read only Others permissions read only Changing Permissions with chmod Symbolic method u+x g+w o-r a+r Numeric method 755 644 777 Changing Ownership with chown Change owner Change owner and group Change recursively Best Practices Never give unnecessary permissions Use group permissions to share access Regularly audit file permissions Use 644 for regular files 755 for executables Master these concepts and you'll have a solid foundation in Linux security

documents.title: Shell Scripting: Automate Your Tasks
documents.content: Shell Scripting Automate Your Tasks Why Shell Scripting Automate daily tasks Create system administration tools Improve productivity Create reproducible processes Chain commands together Your First Shell Script Create hello.sh file Make it executable chmod +x hello.sh Variables name=Alice age=25 Conditionals if [ -f file ]; then Loops for i in {1..5}; do Functions greet() { Practical Example Backup Script Tips for Writing Better Scripts Always use quotes around variables Use meaningful variable names Add comments to explain your code Handle errors with set -e Test scripts thoroughly Make scripts executable chmod +x Shell scripting is a valuable skill

documents.title: Mastering grep Command
documents.content: Mastering grep Command What is grep grep stands for Global Regular Expression Print It searches for lines matching a pattern and prints them to the output Basic Usage grep error logfile.txt grep warning /var/log/syslog Useful Options -i Case-insensitive -c Count matches -n Show line numbers -v Invert match exclude -r Recursive search -E Multiple patterns Practical Examples Find failed logins Count occurrences Search multiple files Find with context Combine with pipes Regular Expressions grep [0-9]{3} file.txt grep ^ERROR file.txt grep .log$ file.txt Tips and Tricks Use grep -i for case-insensitive searches Use grep -n to quickly identify line numbers Combine with other tools using pipes Test patterns on small files first Use grep -E for extended regex patterns Spend time mastering grep

documents.title: Git Essentials Guide
documents.content: Git Essentials Guide What is Git Git is a distributed version control system that tracks changes to your code over time It allows you to collaborate with others revert to previous versions and create branches for new features Basic Configuration git config --global user.name git config --global user.email Essential Commands Initialize a Repository Check Status Stage Changes Commit Changes View History Branching Create branch Switch to branch Create and switch Merge branch Remote Repositories Add remote Push to remote Pull from remote Master these commands and you'll have a solid foundation in version control
